awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Effective Detection of Vulnerabilities and Linguistic Stratification in Open Source Software
awd_abstract_narration:
Software vulnerabilities are weaknesses in the code that may be exploited by cybercriminals to harm a system. They often do not hinder a program's functionality, and are thus difficult to detect. This project focuses on developing methods to identify such "weak spots" in a program, where vulnerabilities are more likely to occur. 

The approach used for detecting weak spots is based on the novel idea of examining linguistic patterns employed by code developers in Open-Source Software (OSS) online communities. Using a combination of natural language processing methods and sociolinguistic analyses, the PIs research the links between a programmer's role within a social hierarchy of trust and influence and his or her skills in producing code that avoids vulnerabilities and adheres to the communal cybersecurity standards. The research results in a faster way to identify vulnerabilities, therefore contributing to make programs safer. It also contributes to understanding of the natural properties of code and the social dynamics of communication in online groups, laying the foundation for further research into linguistic aspects of software engineering.

por.por_cntn:
This project is a collaboration between computer scientists (software engineering) and social scientists (linguistics) to develop a new interdisciplinary approach to address issues in cybersecurity. Code can be made more secure if the developers who are more likely to inadvertently introduce a vulnerability in a program can be somehow identified early. As a first step, we wanted to understanding the specific communicative patterns of software developers in on-line communities, especially those who focus on cybersecurity issues. As a general result, we found positive evidence that favors the use of linguistic evidence to explore group membership among developers collaborating in on-line projects and exchanges of information about their craft. We investigated how developers talked to each other in two on-line platforms: StackOverflow and GitHub. We found out that in Q&A forums like StackOverflow, contributors tend to participate in discussions based on their interests and expertise, rather than choose postings opportunistically in order to maximize their reputation. The data gathered in this way has provided us with a good understanding of the base distribution of linguistic items in the language of code developers, including jargon and technical vocabulary. With respect to GitHub sub-community specific language use, we found that experienced users conform to project-specific language norms, which is a novel result with consequences to cybersecurity and social intrusion detection. Also, we found that popular individuals use a more generic GitHub language rather than project-specific language. Finally, we also found that conformance to project specific language norms reduces issue resolution times, which is relevant more broadly to software engineering efforts. Our analysis of the internal dynamics of participation in Q/A forums will have an impact in theories of communication that try to understand the motivations of actors that volunteer their time to solve other people's problems and to offer support. We argue in favor of a model that downplays immediate rewards for the individual, enhancing the collective benefits of participating in an active community instead. These insights will impact the way in which we understand computer mediated communication and the threats to cybersecurity that emerge within it (flaming, trolling, cyberbullying, etc.). Cybersecurity is a major social concern. We are starting to understand that vulnerabilities and other forms of cybercrime are not just a matter of technology, but that are caused because of the human factor involved in our computer-mediated interactions. OUr research is highlighting the extent to which the linguistic patterns of software developers are different from those of the average population, and how they can be used to gain access to information and trust within a team of developers. By finding ways to put this knowledge to work we will be able to contribute to having a more secure environment for the public to use software and share information safety.
